lesson.title: Gradle Fundamentals
lesson.summary: Learn the syntax and semantics of Gradle build scripts, and understand the lifecycle of a Gradle build.

concepts.title: Welcome to Gradle for Android and Java!

atoms.title: Welcome to Gradle for Android and Java!
atoms.instructor_notes: Udacity's Developing Android Apps course.

atoms.title: Java and Android Builds
atoms.instructor_notes: We will dig deeper into the Android build process in lessons 3 and 4, but if you want to look ahead, here's the Android Build System Overview. Also, welcome to the course Instructor Notes! Down here you can often find helpful links, resources, and clarifications.

atoms.title: Build Tool Advantages
atoms.instructor_notes: To learn more about formative assessment, check out this wiki page. You can also learn more about build tools and build automation. If you're having trouble with the quiz, go ahead and hit the "View Answer" button to check out my solution. Remember, these quizzes are here to help you, not to evaluate you.

atoms.title: Why Gradle
atoms.instructor_notes: Head over to the Gradle website to find out more about the advantages of Gradle, and what sets it apart from other build tools. You might also want to check out this video where Xavier Ducrohet, head of the Android Dev Tools team, talks about the Android build system and why Gradle was chosen as the tool of choice for Android.

atoms.title: Intro to Tasks
atoms.instructor_notes: We'll dig much deeper into tasks in this lesson, but if you want to dive straight into the Gradle tasks documentation, check out this chapter of the Gradle User Guide.

atoms.title: Command Line Gradle
atoms.instructor_notes: Actually, since Gradle 3.0, the daemon is enabled by default! Woo hoo! Note that all code shown in this course is available from the course GitHub repository. The code for this demo is in the 1.01-Exercise-RunYourFirstTask folder. We'll learn more about the Gradle wrapper in lesson 2, but you can check out this chapter of the Gradle User Guide for more info. You can learn more about the Gradle daemon in this chapter of the Gradle User Guide.

atoms.title: Run Your First Task
atoms.instructor_notes: To run your first task, download the course code from the repository here, or you can just clone from: `https://github.com/udacity/ud867.git`. Then follow the instructions in the `build.gradle` file in the 1.01-Exercise-RunYourFirstTask folder. Remember that you can always find help in the `solution.gradle` file in the same folder!

atoms.title: Gradle Installation
atoms.instructor_notes: Note that the GVM tool referred to in the video is now SDKMAN. You can find these instructions in the 1.02-Exercise-InstallGradle folder in the course code. Windows installation instructions are available there as well. More details can also be found in the Installing Gradle chapter of the user guide. Other options for installing Gradle include Homebrew and the SDKMAN tool.

atoms.title: Install Gradle
atoms.instructor_notes: You can find our Gradle installation instructions in the `build.gradle` file in the 1.02-Exercise-InstallGradle folder in the course code. You'll need to run the `gradle helloWorld` command in that directory. Windows installation instructions are available there as well. Remember you can download the course code from the repository here, or you can just clone from: `https://github.com/udacity/ud867.git`. More details can also be found in the Installing Gradle chapter of the user guide. Other options for installing Gradle include Homebrew and the SDKMAN tool. Note that you do not need to install Groovy! Gradle brings along its own Groovy distribution.

atoms.title: Gradle Build Scripts
atoms.instructor_notes: Take a look at this chapter in the Gradle user guide for an overview of Gradle build scripts and the Gradle build language.

atoms.title: Groovy Fundamentals
atoms.instructor_notes: Note that the `sayHello()` task shouldn't be static. The code for this demo is in the 1.03-Demo-GroovyFundamentals folder. Learn X in Y: Groovy. Groovy user guide.

atoms.title: Groovy Closures and Objects
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this demo is in the 1.04-Demo-GroovyClosuresAndObjects folder. Learn X in Y: Groovy. Groovy user guide.

atoms.title: Experiment with Groovy
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this exercise is in the 1.05-Exercise-ExperimentWithGroovy folder. Remember you can find the exercise and quiz solutions in the solution.gradle file! Learn X in Y: Groovy. Groovy user guide.

atoms.title: Task Configuration
Configure a Task
atoms.instructor_notes: Run the console command: ``` gradle -b solution.gradle tasks ``` and see if you can match up what's on the quiz slide with your terminal output! The code for this exercise is in the 1.07-Exercise-ConfigureATask folder. Remember you can find the exercise and quiz solutions in the solution.gradle file!

atoms.title: Task Dependencies and Ordering
atoms.instructor_notes: In this video I accidentally use `mustRunAfter` and `shouldRunAfter` interchangeably, but there's an important difference. In some cases `shouldRunAfter` can be ignored, such as when it would introduce a cyclical dependency, and when executing a parallel build. For more info, check out this [section](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/more_about_tasks.html#sec:ordering_tasks) of the user guide. The code for this demo is in the 1.08-Demo-TaskDependencies folder. You can find the Gradle documentation on task dependencies and ordering here.

atoms.title: Configure Task Dependencies
atoms.instructor_notes: **TRICK QUESTION ALERT!** Okay it wasn't a trick question when it was written. Gradle 3.3 introduced a change where only tasks that are assigned a group are displayed by default by `gradle tasks`, so if you're on 3.3 or later, there isn't an `Other tasks` section at all. On previous versions of Gradle, the tasks in the `Other tasks` section were those that weren't assigned a task group, but did depend on other tasks. In our case, those tasks are `blackCoffee` and `sweetCoffee`. Sorry for the confusion. Ain't making classes about living, changing software great? :P The code for this exercise is in the 1.09-Exercise-ConfigureTaskDependencies folder.

atoms.title: Gradle DSL Reference
atoms.instructor_notes: You can find the Gradle DSL reference here.

atoms.title: Docs Scavenger Hunt
atoms.instructor_notes: You can find the Gradle DSL reference here.

atoms.title: Interacting With The File System
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this demo is in the 1.10-Demo-InteractingWithTheFileSystem folder. Take a look at the Gradle user guide chapter on working with files for more information. Also, the DSL reference page for the Copy task is available here

atoms.title: Configure File System Tasks
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this exercise is in the 1.11-Exercise-ConfigureFileSystemTasks folder.

atoms.title: Incremental Builds
atoms.instructor_notes: Check out this blog post to learn more about incremental builds.

atoms.title: Explore Incremental Builds
atoms.instructor_notes: By "time-stamping", I mean including the date/time in the file name of a build output. The code for this exercise is in the 1.12-Exercise-ExploreIncrementalBuilds folder.

atoms.title: Parameterising Your Build
atoms.instructor_notes: Note that properties in the `ext` block must be declared before they are used (unlike what is shown in this video). For more info on the syntax of `.properties` files, check out [this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.properties). The code for this demo is in the 1.13-Demo-ParameterisingYourBuild folder. More details can be found in this chapter of the Gradle user guide.

atoms.title: Gradle Properties
atoms.instructor_notes: Note that properties in the `ext` block must be declared before they are used. For more info on the syntax of `.properties` files, check out [this article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.properties). The code for this exercise is in the 1.14-Exercise-UseGradleProperties folder. More details can be found in this chapter of the Gradle user guide.

atoms.title: Creating Custom Task Types
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this demo is in the 1.15-Demo-CustomTaskTypes folder. Additional information on writing custom tasks can be found in this chapter of the Gradle user guide.

atoms.title: Create Your Own Task Type
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this exercise is in the 1.16-Exercise-CreateATaskType folder.

question.title: Create Your Own Task Type - Quiz

atoms.title: Troubleshooting and Logging
atoms.instructor_notes: Check out the Gradle User Guide chapter on logging.

atoms.title: Investigate Logging
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this exercise is in the 1.17-Exercise-InvestigateLogging folder. Check out the Gradle User Guide chapter on logging.

atoms.title: Build Lifecycle
atoms.instructor_notes: Take a look at the build lifecycle chapter of the Gradle user guide for more information.

atoms.title: Explore the Build Lifecycle
atoms.instructor_notes: The code for this exercise is in the 1.18-Exercise-ExploreTheBuildLifecycle folder. Take a look at the build lifecycle chapter of the Gradle user guide for more information.
